timeline.author: tdonohue

timeline.bodyText: why are we parsing the json instead than use the existing Matcher? this also apply to all the other tests
timeline.author: abollini

replies.bodyText:
Good point, yes there is a org.dspace.app.rest.matcher.CollectionMatcher which can be used to compare JSON results against a known set of values.  There's some good examples in the CollectionRestRepositoryIT.
In fact, all the tests in this IT should likely be updated to use either CollectionMatcher or CommunityMatcher.  (and those two matchers could be updated with new comparison methods as needed).  I had completely overlooked that in this PR.
replies.author: tdonohue

timeline.bodyText: I don't see any value in adding a more test for AB as this is the same test data category than AA
timeline.author: abollini

timeline.bodyText: we can avoid to retrieve this value from the REST, the findOne endpoint has already test in the specific IT class. Doing it again here will only slow our test
timeline.author: abollini

timeline.bodyText: my suggestion is to remove this test as it is functionally equivalent to col1ParentCommunityTest
timeline.author: abollini

timeline.bodyText:
we need all the test related to the security and wrong scenarios.
The specified item, collection, community

don't exist, don't make sense (i.e. it is not an uuid) -> (404)
are not visibile (401, 403)
the starting object is visible but the parent is not visible (401, 403)
timeline.author: abollini

replies.bodyText:
@abollini : I'm not sure the 404 test is needed, as we already have corresponding 404 tests in ITs for Communities, Collections & Items. How can a 404 test here add anything different?
I do agree that the other two types of tests would be worth adding, though we could consider doing so as a separate security ticket (as you noted), provided that we create a ticket in JIRA.
replies.author: tdonohue

replies.bodyText:
obvious test are useful for the future because they look obvious now that we know the implementation but if we go trough a refactoring the implementation could be completely different and break something that we expect to just work. So I always recommend to make black box test, indeed we should follow a TDD approach that would imply that.
Anyway, I'm not completely sure that it will return 404 right now, maybe we can get a NPE o ClassCastException so a 500 see https://github.com/DSpace/DSpace/pull/2673/files#diff-59c10eaa99f8fbc2322484a9bacff5afR51 (again I'm just guessing but it is wrong to look to the communityservice to get the answer, we need to have test to proof it)
replies.author: abollini

timeline.bodyText: please don't reduce the scope of the matcher as this would have the effect to reduce the usefulness of the existing tests. Instead, if a new match method that exclude embedded is required overload the method
timeline.author: abollini

replies.bodyText: @abollini : This was resolved in a different manner.  A new matchCollectionEntryFullProjection() method was added, and all existing tests that depend on embeds (full projection) were updated to use that new method.
replies.author: tdonohue

timeline.bodyText: again better overload the method than reduce the checks
